Award.AwardTitle: Student Mentoring to Achieve Retention: Triads in Science (SMARTS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Student Mentoring to Achieve Retention: Triads in Science program (SMARTS) at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) has as its primary goals to encourage more underrepresented and financially disadvantaged students to persist as science majors, complete their degrees in a timely manner, enhance their interest in pursuing advanced degrees, and provide them with the tools necessary to become skilled scientists and educators, so that they are able to compete effectively in the global academic and technical workforce. To realize these goals, the program uses an innovative approach that involves the formation of mentoring teams consisting of one faculty member, one graduate student and one undergraduate student (junior or senior level), who form a mentoring triad. The program has three main objectives: 1) achieve full retention of talented but financially disadvantaged undergraduate students (juniors and seniors) majoring in the sciences, while significantly reducing their time to graduation; 2) increase the number of undergraduates, particularly members of underrepresented minorities, who elect and are well-prepared to pursue advanced degrees in the sciences; and 3) recruit more graduate students to become educators and research mentors in the sciences. Through the triad approach, undergraduates learn to work effectively in teams and learn from practitioners what to expect in future years. Graduate students hone their team-building and mentoring skills, which is valuable as they pursue educational, leadership and managerial roles in STEM fields. The program also enriches the professional training of graduate students through several of the program workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the Student Mentoring to Achieve Retention: Triads in Science program (SMARTS) at the University of Texas at El Paso was to form mentoring-triad teams consisting of one faculty member, one graduate student and one undergraduate student (junior or senior level) to encourage both undergraduate and graduate students to persist as science majors, complete their degrees in a timely manner, provide them with the tools necessary to become skilled scientists and educators, and enhance the undergraduates’ interest to pursue advanced degrees.

Thirty seven (37) students participated in the program, 21 undergraduate and 17 graduate (one undergraduate became a graduate fellow in the program). All were financially underprivileged and the majority of them (76% of the undergraduate and 69% of the graduate students) are from underrepresented groups. The program included:

a) Participation by all triad members in a yearly mentoring workshop, where they learned (or reviewed) the fundamentals of an effective mentor-mentee relationship and outlined the responsibilities of each individual to all members of the triad. At the workshops all members drafted their individual mentoring plan, which included a skills self-assessment and their short and long-term academic and career objectives.

b) A senior capstone course, which despite being optional for juniors, all juniors elected to participate in. The course included engagement of undergraduates in a research project, guided by the graduate student and faculty mentors, participation in a series of professional training workshops and presentation at a local and/or national conference.

c) Participation of graduate students in workshops tailored to their own professional development.  

 

The program had 3 main objectives as outlined below with their respective expected and achieved outcomes:

Objective 1:

 Achieve full retention of talented but financially disadvantaged undergraduate students (juniors and seniors) majoring in the sciences, while significantly reducing their time to graduation. Expected outcome: 80% of all undergraduates served by the SMARTS program will 1a) remain in the sciences and 1b) graduate in 5 years or less.

Achieved outcome:

  • 21 undergraduate students participated in the program. Four left the program for different reasons: Accepted into a program with better benefits (1); Did not qualify for financial aid any more (1); Changed to a non-STEM major (1); Changed to a STEM related major that did not fall into the proposed ones (1)
  • 20 out of the 21 (95%) undergraduate fellows remained in the sciences
  • 19 graduated with Bachelor’s degree: 18 with STEM degrees and one with a STEM related degree (nursing).
  • One student left the sciences and one student is still enrolled as an undergraduate in a STEM program.
  • All 19 who graduated did it in 5 years or less.

Objective 2:

 Increase the number of undergraduate students, particularly members of underrepresented minorities, who elect and are well prepared to pursue advanced degrees in the sciences. Expected outcome: 50% of all undergraduates served by the SMARTS program will elect to pursue advanced degrees in the sciences.

Achieved outcome:

  • Of the 19 fellows who graduated,
    • 13 are pursuing advanced degrees: 12 in STEM (63%) and 1 an MBA;  
    • 3 are pursuing additional research experience (post-back programs): 2 to gain entry into graduate programs, and 1 to gain entry into  medical school;
    • 2 have unknown whereabouts and
    • 1 is working as a nurse (see bullet below)
  • Of the 4 who left the program,
    • the 2 that remained in STEM are pursuing graduate degrees in STEM;
    • the 1 that switched to nursing is working as a nurse;
    • the 1 that switched to a non-STEM major is still enrolled.

Objective 3:

Recruit more graduate students interested in and train them to become educators and research mentors in the sciences. Expected outcome: 50% of all graduate students served by the SMARTS program will elect to become educators and research mentors in the sciences.

Achieved outcome:

  • All 17 (100%) graduate fellows were retained in their respective science majors
  • Of the 17 graduate fellows,
    • 11 (65%) completed degrees (7 Master’s and 4 Doctoral); 2 of the Master’s degree recipients continued on to pursue doctoral degrees (still enrolled);
    • 4 are still enrolled (1 in the Master’s program and 3 in doctoral programs).
    • Only 1 doctoral student left the university before graduating due to spouse re-location.
  •  All participants who were doctoral recipients are currently in post-doctoral positions
